title: A Point-by-Point analysis on why Shen feels much weaker now. (Rather lengthy post, you were warned)
body:
[](https://static.lolwallpapers.net/2016/01/Warlord-Shen.jpg)
Many people have been asking me why Shen is much weaker than before. I didn't know what they were talking about before I binge played him like I usually do, and I realized the issues he has with his kit that make him feel like he possesses much less strength than before. He's not underpowered, he actually has very good potential to be a god tier top laner with his new mechanics, but the actual execution of these tools is extremely awkward.
____________________________________
#**1. Shen's spirit blade feels more like an anchor than a tool for battle.**
___________________________________
This is because the positioning of the sword is impossible to control without using your Q or your ultimate. The tether distance is way too far to be smooth, and actually is counter-intuitive to its purpose of positioning it right. Shen players like to have the advantage of being able to utilize their E however they wish, because it's basic and easy to use. A linear skillshot that can move through units and walls. But the addition of another element makes it a bit foreign, and changes up the play style quite a bit. 

Not only is the tether range too far, but the speed of the sword is too slow to be utilized efficiently. Opponents see that you used your Q the moment you press the button, but the sword itself can take up to 3 seconds just to get to you. Not to mention that the buff on your Q doesn't occur until your sword hits your model, opponents can easily back off and wait out your failed engage before retaliating and punishing you for trying. 

#**Possible solutions**

It's a matter of utility and speed. **Either decrease the tether range dramatically, or sharply increase the missile speed of the spirit blade. ** This will decrease the arrival time of a distant spirit blade, making it a threat even from so far away. It also reduces the "delayed utility" feeling you get when playing Shen, as his blade will be more reliable in lane and during trades. There is currently no utility or counterplay associated with Shen having his blade be far away from himself. Your opponent would not know what is in the fog of war, how close your blade is, and there is no strategic value to have a blade be a Nocturne ult's worth of distance away from your lane. It's just a mechanic that makes spamming his Q all the more viable, which is not something a strategic dueling tank like Shen should do. He is meant to pick his fights carefully, positioning and pulling off risky engages in order to gain the upper hand on his opponents. Good players would counter this by relying on side stepping his E (which is relatively easy to do), and watching Shen's movements to watch for any behavioral cues.

Another possible solution, a rather radical one in itself, is to **allow Shen to reposition his sword at will without utilizing his Q**. This would clear up any inconsistencies and clunkiness associated with his sword's distance, but would come at the price of clarity and simplicity. This idea has been entertained by many, but while it seems logical it would make Shen feel too much like Orianna, in my opinion.
____________________________________
#**2. Twilight Assault (Q) feels extremely clunky and unrewarding for a skirmishing and trading tool.**
______________________________________
This is attributed to two things. First, Shen's Q auto attack buff doesn't start until the moment his blade reaches him. Second: the auto attacks themselves take too long to proc and are easy to retreat from. When playing Shen in the top lane, you usually don't have the tools to fight some of the more powerful top laners like {{champion:41}} or {{champion:62}}. Both can easily retreat should they suspect something, and can punish heavily for walking away from a failed engage. Shen theoretically has the tools to counter this, but they are not very reliable.

Many a time, Shen players have engaged while pulling in the blade through their opponent. However, by the time the blade has reached them, the opponent is already ahead of the Shen player and/or out of the taunt duration. While I do agree that Shen needs to be melee in order to give him ways to be countered, I feel like the slow on his Q isn't as punishing as it should, given the qualifications needed to actually pull it off. It takes careful positioning, planning, and outright reaction time in order to get a good engage with the Q, but it only takes a simple side step from your opponent or a 50 unit retreat in order to negate all that effort.

#**Possible Solutions**
The best way to make Shen's Q feel less clunky and more rewarding lies in the reward for landing the Q on an opponent and the actual method of using it. **Either increase the slow's duration and/or strength for pulling a spirit blade through an opponent or let the auto attack buffs prematurely activate.** Increasing the duration of the slow could help deal with the slew of utility and escape tools top laners can have, inhibiting their movement further or for longer gives Shen a bigger window to force a fight to be in his favor, to reward good play and careful planning. This will separate the success rates between good Shens and great Shens. Should the latter be implemented, the actual blade's positioning could be used as a complimentary slow in exchange for the extra damage. For example, the tooltip could be read as follows:
>Should the Spirit blade not reach Shen within .75 seconds, Shen's next three attacks are empowered anyway.

This would not only create some breathing room for Shen players, but give them options to actually think about. "Should I wait for my blade to pass through for extra damage or should I use my attacks now in order to avoid the risk of my opponent getting away unscathed?" This is the buff that could make Shen enter competitive play as a top laner again, as his versatility and strengths are exclusive against immobile, auto-attack oriented top laners. This could broaden the spectrum a bit, making Shen less of a super niche pick and more of a champion that can be played to complement his team's strengths while utilizing his own. Against champions like {{champion:92}}  and {{champion:58}}, who can simply CC Shen and walk away once they realize he's going in, Shen can actually have the tools to hold his own against lanes with good disengage. Albeit they will be just as difficult as ever, but not impossible.
____________________________________
#**3. Spirit's Refuge (W) is extremely powerful on its own, but nearly impossible to utilize correctly.**
____________________________________
This ties back to Shen's spirit blade feeling more like an anchor than an actual pillar of strength. The positioning on Shen's W is extremely awkward, as the blade is almost always stationary when not being dragged around with Shen's Q. However, it also is attributed to the fact that using it punishes Shen very hard, even if he does use it at a very crucial moment. The massive cooldown of 18 seconds (12 when maxed out) is a good way to inhibit Shen's ability to spam it (inb4 URF mode Shen becoming Jax during the dodge era), but for a defensive tool it is extremely taxing to use. You lose 40 energy, which doesn't seem like much by itself, but when considering that the cooldown itself doesn't go down by much makes you think that the effect would last longer than 1.75 seconds when maxed out. The cooldown is too high, the energy cost isn't necessary because it's already inhibited by the cooldown, and for what it takes to position it right in the heat of battle, it doesn't offer much.

#**Possible Solutions**
Shen's problems with his W lie in the lackluster reward for what is given in return. There is no reason to level up Spirit Refuge (W) at the moment because max level only gives you a cooldown reduction of 6 seconds. It doesn't feel like there is a reason to level it up even in the most defensive playstyle. **Remove the unnecessary energy cost, lower its cooldown, or increase the protective zone duration per ability level.** Removing the energy cost would only make sense, since as mentioned before, the cooldown is enough to gate it. An energy cost is a joke and serves no real purpose but to make awkward situations where you're 40 energy short for an ability. Should the energy cost stay, the cooldown of the actual ability should be reduced per level, perhaps at a decent 8 seconds when maxed out. This would make his W actually feel involved, and less like an ability to use then forget about. Additionally, the energy cost would actually make sense. The final of the three would be, in my opinion, the most logical. The protective zone, even at max rank, feels like a poor excuse of a defensive ability, since it doesn't feel like a tide-turning ability late game as it is. Increasing the duration to something reasonable late game, say to a decent 2.5-3 seconds (Ok, 3 seconds seems a bit excessive, but you get my point) would be better.)

Another solution that seems a bit more farfetched could be to **add a health shield to the protective zone exclusively for allies.** The original issue I found with this was that Shen would abuse the crap out of the extra health shield in lane, and be unkillable. The solution is to give it only to allies. This way, for the measly 1.75 second dodge zone, you can protect your team from AoE abilities and spells while inside the zone as well. It'd feel more like a "Spirit's Refuge" rather than a "Spirit's Bullet Time Zone." However, this change might actually break Shen, so we never know.

______________________________

**_Thank you for reading. I know this post was a little on the lengthy side, but I just wanted to express my views on the new Shen rework and possible suggestions that could be implemented to make his gameplay feel better. This is not a thread clamoring for Shen buffs. This is a subjective analysis._
**

P.S: Don't start any comment wars. This is a place for discussion, not for a poor imitation of Comedy Central's roast sessions.

replies.body: Miss the damage reduction from taunted players during the laning phase.
Yeah, that was always a kicker against champions like {{champion:92}}.

I played Old Shen quite a bit, so far only have a handful of games with New Shen:

A lot of it, for me, comes down to the fact that they kind of force Shen to combo his abilities in ways that either don't feel smooth, or feel counter-intuitive.

They removed the damage reduction from Shadow Dash. "Ok, well, his W now dodges everything, so maybe they're forcing him to use his W for the "reduction" effect he would otherwise get." And since he gets refunded energy per target Taunted, and he could theoretically taunt several targets, this makes sense. The point where Shen is likely to get the most mileage out of it is during a 3-5 person taunt (in terms of most damage dodged).

But, his W is based on his Q location. "Okay, so Shen needs to taunt, then pull the sword with his Q, and *then* he can use his W." But this, then, forces him into a situation where he's heavily combo reliant. In turn, this makes it difficult to use his tools individually. Say you're losing a fight, running from the enemy team. "Oh, I want to protect my carry. I'll use W. OH WAIT I have to Q first to move it over to me." And that's assuming that you're sticking with your carry and not trying to, you know, peel. Which is what you're supposed to do.

He spams his Q for any amount of damage output, plus moving his sword; but I don't know how many times I was in a fight and Yi or Jax or Riven jumps into the fight and I hit W... and nothing happened.... because my Q was on CD and it didn't move the W to me. part of that is just getting used to the kit, but overall his kit is less reactive than before.

And again, the AoE dodge makes him feel like he should be protecting his carries, but his Taunt wants to go peel/CC priority targets.

Not to mention the number of times an enemy has barely gotten away because I no longer have any range... I'm willing to part with that, though if the rest of his kit actually felt cohesive.


As for your suggestions; instead of speeding up his Q speed, I'd rather it have a flat "time to Shen." i.e, Shen summons his spirit blade, traveling to him over 1.5 seconds" or something. The issue I would see with speeding it up is, honestly, at short range (mostly in laning phase) I find it pretty easy to hit with it because of how fast it already is. This would slow it down at short ranges, but again I don't have much problem with hitting it as it is. But if it were far away, it'd move faster in order to get to him in the same amount of time. it would also make the "time to Shen" standardized which would let him (and his opponent) try to time and feel out the delay. I admit this would make it easier to walk away, so I'd suggest upping the Slow speed in this case.

> As for your suggestions; instead of speeding up his Q speed, I'd rather it have a flat "time to Shen." i.e, Shen summons his spirit blade, traveling to him over 1.5 seconds" or something. 

Instead of it having a set travel time, it could be "Spirit Blade returns to Shen within 1.5 seconds" so if it is closer, you wouldn't have to wait 1.5 sec but if its far away, it will travel faster to make it there in time.
This is a very good suggestion.

I like Shen's new abilities and passive, but I don't like the sword at all. It does feel like an anchor and, besides the W, it doesn't really feel like we're playing around it in a positive way. The sword doesn't help Shen or his allies, and it barely hurts his enemies (in terms only of a situational slow). I say just get rid of the sword and make some slight adjustments to his Q and W to compensate.

Also, it is annoying feeling that his Q doesn't reset autos.

I'd also like to mention that he sucks at most matchups in toplane because of being purely melee with a long cd missable taunt (that in most cases has to be used in conjuction with W because making someone attack you that is actually building AD is less than ideal without a way to mitigate it)

And for a purely melee champion his base stats are actually terrible (check it, base armor worse than an adcs)

I kind of miss being able to duel top laners more easily. Now they walk all over you if they know what they're doing. Skill is starting to become less of a factor now, because Shen's way too slow for his play style.

I miss being able to do things without having to rely on E for everything. People run away on low health all the time after the taunt ends and since the Q slow is so short and situational you rarely ever catch up.

I honestly feel like a weird Warwick when playing this Shen, being so AA reliant with the only way of closing the distance being a taunt that has a long cooldown.
Maybe a speed boost for Shen if he lands his sword would be nice. I mean, he's full melee, where's the harm in a slight speed boost toward his marked enemy?

One of the biggest problems with Shen is that now you have to work 3 times harder to achieve the same effectiveness as the old Shen. With old Shen you can safely farm and poke when needed. Current Shen you have no poke and in order to deal any amount of harass you must full on engage. As basically a pure melee, he is worse in almost every regard compared to his former. 

His lane power has dropped into almost nothing. Jungle is where he maybe excels at now but even then it's still extremely weak compared to his competition.

I've only played rework Shen like 3 times before RQing but IMO here are his biggest downfalls:

-No range
-No sustain
-Low dmg
-Low sticking power
-Taunt hit box is tiny
-Is supposed to be a split pusher but loses or at least gets stalled out 1v1 to almost anyone

I just tjink the whole spiritblade thing is rather stupid on Shen.
Carrying a giant floating glowstick around is unfitting on multiple levels for him imo.
It looks ankward, takes away alot screenspace and actually has very little gameplay.
Even if it was more reliable, he stll woud be prettyuch 'spam Q and rightclick, hopeing your opponent doesn't simply walk away'
His only somewhat strong point is E->Q->W, outside of that combo he's really weak with his low basestats and all his amage bound to multiple AAs whil he has poor tools to stick onto a target.
I think most important for new shen is too get rid of the spiritblade and completely turn it into an active

Surprised no one has commented yet-

This is a great post. I'm not a Shen main or anything but I did play him frequently and I don't like the changes that were made on him. I agree with what you've written ( but I doubt anything will be done about it ).

Well, Riot has been shown to read posts from time to time. While it may not seem like it at times, they actually peruse the boards and help out where they can. Maybe we can get some kind of insight into what further changes are planned for Shen.

The changes themselves are fine, since Shen plays similarly to how he did before. But the mechanics themselves need some tweaking.
Would love the sword to be faster. It is frustrating to wait for it when you really need it.

It's like that one friend who always comes like an hour late to your parties.

"Traffic, bro."

As a Shen main I too would like to address the problems with his new kit. And I will compare every skill to the old one, including stats.

**Ki strike CD 9/8/7**

Shen's basic attacks periodically deal 8 - 76 (based on level) (+ 10% bonus health) bonus magic damage and restore 10 / 20 / 30 energy.
Every basic attack reduces Ki Strike's cooldown by 1 second, doubled to 2 seconds while Feint holds.

_His old bread and butter passive, damage and energy management in one complete package. Rewards Shen for being aggressive. Able to proc multiple times in a prolonged fight especially with W._

**Ki barrier CD 10**

After using an ability, Shen shields himself from 52 - 120 (based on level) (+ 14% bonus health) damage for 2.5 seconds. Abilities that successfully affect champions reduce Ki Barrier's cooldown by 4 - 7.5 (based on level) seconds.
Shen's power manifests as a Spirit Blade that he can control with abilities.

_Supposedly the trade off for removing old Shen's good sustain in lane, while a decent shield stat wise. Not on demand and too short of a duration to really do anything. The only skill where that shield should be delayed is his ult, all the others should activate it on cast. If it has a low duration, it needs to be on demand. I feel this is a direct nerf compared to Ki strike which was a really good passive before he got reworked (again). He is full melee auto attack reliant, lets not be silly and give him some power._




**Vorpal Blade RANGE: 475 COST: 60 ENERGY CD: 6 / 5.5 / 5 / 4.5 / 4**

ACTIVE: Shen throws a blade at the target enemy, dealing them magic damage and marking them for 5 seconds.
MAGIC DAMAGE: 60 / 100 / 140 / 180 / 220 (+ 60% AP)

Shen and allied champions heal over 3 seconds upon damaging a marked enemy, with the duration refreshing with subsequent damage.
HEAL PER SECOND: 1 / 2 / 3 / 4 / 5 (+ 0.5% maximum health) 
MAXIMUM HEAL: 8 / 16 / 24 / 32 / 40 (+ 4% maximum health)

If Vorpal Blade kills its target, Shen instantly benefits from a second's worth of its healing.

_Old Shen's only threatening ability, a low damage **low range** spammable point and click ranged ability. People have been complaining that this ability is pretty much free poke and it is, if you are unaware of the existence of magic resist. It is a low damage ability which means Spectre's Cowl effectively counters it (and Ki strike's damage). While being a relative cheap item to rush, complain about Shen outtrading you while you rush AD. While Shen rushes a Sunfire Cape, boosting his damage/sustain/tankyness, and then wonder why you lost. I agree that the ability was too easy to use, but be mindful of its extremely short range and that its use for poking will only work in lane. The only time I miss this ability is when a enemy champ is walking away with a sliver of health, E is on its huge cooldown/flash not up and I am just outside of AA range. Where is my sword of justice?_

**Twilight Assault	RANGE: 200 COST: 140 / 130 / 120 / 110 / 100 ENERGY CD: 8 / 7.25 / 6.5 / 5.75 / 5**

ACTIVE: Shen recalls his Spirit Blade to his location and Twilight Assault empowers his next 3 basic attacks within 8 seconds to deal bonus magic damage. Enemies the blade collides with are Slow icon slowed by 35% for the next 2 seconds when moving away from Shen.

MAGIC DAMAGE: 3 / 3.5 / 4 / 4.5 / 5% (+ 1.5% per 100 AP) of target's max. health 

If the Spirit Blade collides with an enemy champion, the empowerment is Twilight Assault strongly enhanced, dealing 2% (+ 0.5% per 100 AP) of target's maximum health bonus damage and gain 50% bonus attack speed.

ENHANCED MAGIC DAMAGE: 5 / 5.5 / 6 / 6.5 / 7% (+ 2% per 100 AP) of target's max. health

Empowered attacks against non-champions deal additional damage, but their damage is capped.
NON-CHAMPION BONUS DAMAGE: 30 / 50 / 70 / 90 / 110

_Credit where credit is due, the animations are super cool. I love them and I feel that the Q is pretty powerful if people actually stand and fight you. If they ignore you, not so much. The slow is too insignificant for the difficulty of actually landing the blade on a enemy champ, it should slow them regardless with a smaller slow so you can at least use it to retreat. I like the enhanced damage for Twilight Assault, but I wish the final strike had a small range increase. The thing that bothers me the most about this skill is, that is not on demand like his passive. Does not reset auto attacks, has a ap scaling while Shen can't build ap. I'm not suggesting that it should scale with health or armor, that would break it. Shen needs something that makes him stick long enough to champs to do his auto attacks, so I suggest moving the slow to his auto attacks if the blade is pulled through an enemy and greatly enhancing it.
_




**Feint	COST: 50 ENERGY CD: 9 / 8 / 7 / 6 / 5**
	
ACTIVE: Shen shields himself for up to 3 seconds.
SHIELD: 60 / 100 / 140 / 180 / 220 (+ 60% AP)

_Simple on demand shield, boring but effective._

**Spirit's Refuge	COST: 40 ENERGY CD: 18 / 16.5 / 15 / 13.5 / 12**

ACTIVE: Shen primes his Spirit Blade for 2 seconds, causing it to project a protective zone around it for 1.75 seconds if he or an allied champion move nearby, granting allies in the zone 100% dodge chance.

_I like it, but also hate it. Its very hard to keep track of the blade location in a teamfight, and I feel it is only good against auto reliant champs like Yi (duh). The cost is super low, and the CD is super high. Effectively removing another short cooldown ability on Shen, while giving him a minuscule window of opportunity against certain champs. I'd rather the cost and CD were changed a bit, so his ability costs more but has less CD because of it. Maybe allies could also benefit from Ki Barriers shield while inside the field, so AOE is mitigated a little (since it won't help against autos)._





**Shadow Dash RANGE: 600 COST: 100 / 95 / 90 / 85 / 80 ENERGY CD: 16 / 14 / 12 / 10 / 8**

ACTIVE: Shen dashes in the target direction, dealing magic damage to all enemy champions he hits, Taunt icon taunting them for 1.5 seconds and restoring 40 energy per target hit.

MAGIC DAMAGE: 50 / 85 / 120 / 155 / 190 (+ 50% AP)

Taunted opponents deal half damage to Shen with their basic attacks.

_The only bad thing about this ability was the AP scaling, yet that was only a minor gripe._

**Shadow Dash 	RANGE: 600 COST: 180 ENERGY CD: 18 / 16 / 14 / 12 / 10**

PASSIVE: Shadow Dash's and Twilight Assault's damage recovers 30 / 35 / 40 energy.

ACTIVE: Shen dashes in the target direction, dealing physical damage to all enemy champions he hits and Taunt icon taunting them for 1.5 seconds.
PHYSICAL DAMAGE: 50 / 85 / 120 / 155 / 190 (+ 12% bonus health)

_Lets compare the two. _

Old dash costs 50% to 40% energy to cast but replenishes 20% energy per champ hit. 
Old dash dealt a small amount of magic damage.
Old dash halves damage taken from auto's.
Old dash scales with ap.

New dash costs 45% energy across the board and replenishes 10% energy at max rank.
New dash deals physical damage.
New dash scales with hp dealing up to 240 extra aoe damage if you have 2000 bonus health.
New dash has a longer CD.

Conclusion:
Its nerfed, hard. Shen's taunt was never about dealing damage, I always felt guilty stealing a kill when all I meant to do was taunt that champ for my team. It replenishes only half the energy the old taunt did, though that doesn't bother me as much. The cost increase hurts especially when you miss it more so than old Shen, simply because double energy pool = not double energy regen. So why, why is his signature taunt nerfed in cooldown while he is full melee now. Extra damage does not make up for the fact that it does nothing to enhance his tanking, mobility and utility. Damage is the last stat that Shadow Dash needs, if anything it should be removed and his CD should be reduced. Allowing a good Shen to taunt multiple times and a bad Shen to run out of energy in a heartbeat.






**Stand United	RANGE: Global CD: 180 / 160 / 120**

ACTIVE: Shen channels for 3 seconds, granting the target allied champion a  shield that lasts up to 5 seconds.

SHIELD: 250 / 550 / 850 (+ 135% AP)

If the channel completes successfully, Shen blinks to his target, placing himself between them and the nearest visible enemy champion.

_Always fellt weak at level 1, I was hoping a cooldown reduction if the target is killed before the channel ends. It has a really strong ap scaling, while Shen can't build ap._

**Stand United	RANGE: Global CD: 180 / 150 / 120**

ACTIVE: Shen channels for 3 seconds, granting the target allied champion an absorption shield that lasts up to 5 seconds.

SHIELD: 250 / 550 / 850 (+ 130% AP)

Upon completing the channel, Shen and his Spirit Blade Stand United Shield blink to the ally's location.

_They nerfed the ap scaling, lol. Though I'd rather see it go for a halved cooldown if the target expires before channeling ends, or the ability to activate W on the target during channeling. _

Lo and behold all his stats save his movespeed/mr and hp5 (lol) were nerfed. So we take his range, his stats, his sustain and all he gets back is damage. This is nothing short of a disappointment. 

They made Shen pure melee and then dumpstered his stats, mobility and utility in favor of damage. ~~A tank.~~

Radical Idea: Instead of Q causing the sword to move to Shen's location, the sword zips to where you aim it. This gives Shen some long range utility as he can slow more reliably and making E more easy to land in the process. This will help him a big deal against many matchups where he has a range disadvantage. He's a tank, not a juggernaut, so he should be able to get to his opponents with tools other than his dash. 

It also solves the problem of it being an anchor for Shen.  Since the sword will no longer snap to Shen, it makes sense to give him the Q buff when he casts it. The sword won't be getting to him anyways. 

Being able to move the sword to somewhere other than your position also helps with using W. You could send it toward the enemy before taunting to prep the dodge field. You can also help allies significantly easier as you don't have to get to their position with Shen. Just send the sword and press W. Boom. Carry Saved... ideally.

Shen maintains individuality and uniqueness as he will be the only champion in game to have a moving, detached entity the whole game. The targeting for this ability will also be similar to Zed Q firing from his shadow. A similarity that is appropriate considering their history I think.  This change will make the spirit sword significantly less clunky imo.

This idea is surprisingly feasible. The technology is there, and while it doesn't really synergize all too well with his E (and takes a lot more prediction), I feel like this could be a possible fix to his range. While that may not necessarily be a good thing, it's actually something worth trying.

Risk vs Reward is something to think about as well:

Currently, Shen has a single trade pattern once he hits 3:

Dash, Q/W, AA, AA, AA, walk away. The rewards are very lackluster being as you have to use your entire kit just to trade and missing the taunt leaves you with a guaranteed lost trade and no fall back.

In short, there is too little reward for how much risk Shen has to do his trading. 

Late game, Shen can still be a monster problem, and 1.75 seconds is a lot of missed damage by an AA adcs like jinx or tristana, but this does very little to stop the likes of Corki, Varus, Lucian and has pretty well no effect on other kinds of champions.  This makes Shen VERY niche pick as a support OR as a top lane.

Shen has no fall back plan, and cant fight ranged characters at all. Currently, he is pinned down pretty hard as a super niche pick vs melee aa champs in top lane, vs melee supports in the bot lane, and aa adc champs in general. Very risky pick, very risky playstyle, but with VERY little reward. Still feels like old Shen: Just make it to late game, be a super tank that splits and ults in. I just cant safely farm under turret anymore vs ranged champs.

Some solutions I have heard/like:

- Make Q deal damage when passing through a champion.

-Make the Slow for Q passthrough a SLOW... increase its strength and have it work normally, not just when walking away from Shen. 

-Have the mini slow (low strength, only when walking away from Shen) apply to enemies hit by his empowered autos, regardless of pass-through.

-Have Spirit Refuge reduce AoE dmg by a small amount.

-Have Spirit Refuge either last longer with level (start at 1.5 and go up .25 per rank) and/or lower its cooldown.

-Lower the cooldown of Shadow Dash when you hit an enemy champion, rewarding you for success and giving you back your escape option. Still lose your escape if you fail to land the dash.
